At over 59%, our cask strength should be taken seriously. It is barrier-filtered only just to remove the small char particles. This means you will enjoy Laphroaig in its purest form. Expect a slightly sweet, vanilla nuttiness. Timeline Photos

Strong, peaty and smokey whiskies like Laphroaig go perfectly with strong cheeses. This Christmas, make sure you have some Roquefort or stilton on your cheeseboard. Or really go for it with some of our own cheddar http://bit.ly/2eQMEkV Timeline Photos

Whisky tasting tip: Catch the Laphroaig aromas in the right glass. A snifter is best - with a wide base and narrow opening. This allows you to swirl the whisky and release your favourite flavours. If you don’t have one at home, a wine glass is a good substitute. Timeline Photos

October is Breast Cancer Awareness month and Friday 26th October is the 10th “Wear it Pink” day.  “Wear it Pink” is the Breast Cancer Campaign’s biggest fundraiser, having raised more than £22 million to date.

All you have to do is wear something pink on 26th October and donate £2 or more to the Breast Cancer Campaign either via the website at www.breastcancercampaign.org or by making a donation at The Royal Bank of Scotland branch in Bowmore.

http://www.wearitpink.org.uk/getinvolved Timeline Photos

Did you know we can personalise labels of 10 Year Old in our shop? http://www.laphroaig.com/shop/product.aspx?ShopItemID=43 Timeline Photos
Our 10 Year Old is smokier than a barbecue on Islay. And thanks to all the rain we get, it’s more reliable too. Timeline Photos

We don’t fix things that aren’t broken. That’s why our Laphroaig 10 Year Old is made the same way as Ian Hunter invented it 75 years ago. Expect a bold, smoky flavour with a long, sweet finish. Timeline Photos
Islay peat: It's what gives Laphroaig its "30 year old wet leather moccasins held together by 15 year old band aids" taste. (Thanks to Robert Beatty for such a poetic opinion!) Timeline Photos

A stunningly complex marriage of the classical styles and ages of Laphroaig.

Drawing from the very best liquid from a range of cask types including ex-Bourbon, Oloroso Sherry hogsheads and quarter casks, Laphroaig Lore is the story of Laphroaig itself.

Coming to a store near you soon. Timeline Photos

Last month Laphroaig won 3 prizes at the Stockholm Beer and Whisky festival;

The 18YO won Gold and the Vintage 1989 won Silver in the 'Peaty Malt - 13 year old and older' -category and the Quarter Cask came won Silver in the 'Peaty Malt - up to 8 year old' -category.

We are always very excited when Laphroaig receives recognition like this, so thank you Stockholm!

It all comes down to the people working hard on the site, ensuring our traditions are upheld to produce the best possible liquid we can Timeline Photos

A favorite by many, our Quarter Cask is a great expression that highlights an old tradition of doing secondary maturing in smaller casks to increase the contact with wood that adds sweeter notes.

Learn More: http://www.laphroaig.com/whiskies/quarter-cask.aspx Timeline Photos

Let Laphroaig Distillery Manager John Campbell guide you through the Tasting Notes for our superb Quarter Cask: http://bit.ly/QuarterCaskTastingNotes Laphroaig Quarter Cask - Tasting Notes Laphroaig Quarter Cask takes its inspiration from the small casks often used for Scotch Whisky in the 19th century and frequently transported across the Glen...

We're proud to say we are now the owners of not one, not two, but three gold medals from the Beverage Testing Institute competition, with Quarter Cask, 10 Year Old (Cask Strength) and Triple Wood earning 93, 91 and 92 respectively out of a possible 100 points. Slainte! Timeline Photos

Cairdeas Origin 2012 is launched

We specially retained some of our very first Cairdeas for the ‘Friends’ 18th birthday expression .This whisky is now between 13 and 21 years old. We then blended it  (50:50) with some new spirit fully matured in quarter casks for 7 years and bottled it without any chill filtering for maximum flavour. It is at 51.2%ABV strength, which was one of the staff’s ideas, so that the last 2 digits match the year of production .It’s a fantastic ‘coming of age’ whisky, we hope you love it as much as we do! 

Will go on sale at our online shop W/C 18th June.

Tasting Notes.
Nose: With a nose that constantly evolves and is full of flavour Cairdeas Origin begins with a quick hint of concentrated orange moving quickly into huge peat flavours, ashy , dusty with hazelnut. It becomes crisp and fresh with cold green apples, grapes and finishing with a fresh cut grassy flavour.

Palate: The flavours evolve slowly on the palate and with great body it begins with white pepper moving into an earthy peaty flavour, some slight salt then purple heather. Huge creamy apricots that last and last and it ends with some charred damp wood. Timeline Photos

The annual Whisky Nosing Competition for Feis Ile got underway tonight at the Ramsay hall at Port Ellen. Each Islay distillery hosts a table on which there are 11 nosing glasses. Of the 11 glasses, there is a whisky from each distillery plus two unaged spirits. It’s for the public to identify them. 

You may be aware that it helps to move the whisky around in the glass before you sniff, but did you know you should also remember to open your mouth? It helps to focus the senses on the aromas rather than the alcohol. Timeline Photos

Meet the panel:
The first member of this years panel needs no introductions; It's John Campbell!
John Campbell was named Laphroaig’s distillery manager in 2006, fulfilling a 12-year-old ambition. He is the youngest distiller on the island and the first Ileach (native of Islay) to run Laphroaig in its 199 year history. Since joining Laphroaig in 1994, John has worked across the whole distilling process both at Laphroaig and in distilleries including Tormore, Miltonduff and Ardmore.

In addition to his role as Distillery Manager, John plays a lead role in promoting Laphroaig around the world. This includes running the distillery’s “Friends of Laphroaig” program.

John Campbell grew up in the shadow of Laphroaig, and now, he’s running the distillery! Timeline Photos

Next week, from the 15th to the 18th of September, John Campbell will be visiting 4 cities in Germany to taste the no.1 peaty single malt as well as share the latest news on all things Laphroiaig!

After our last question of "If Laphroaig were a film what film would it be" we've been inundated with people asking what our answer was. The last one of the Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiaries is ReJIG.

Since 2006, Re-JIG has been removing marine litter from the shores of Islay and Jura, lifting a total of over 200 tons of litter. Due to a change in the government’s funding policy, Re-JIG will have a shortfall of £19,000 in 2015 and this deficit will continue to grow, soon making it impossible to keep Islay’s beaches clean.

The Laphroaig Legacy fund is helping ensure this invaluable work continues by commissioning a digital project team to monetise the websites and create an online system that enables tourists to donate a small amounts to keep Islay’s beaches clean. This will generate a regular income to finance not only paid employee’s at Re-JIG, but help purchase equipment for the devoted volunteers who are already committed.

Read more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/rejig.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

The next Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiary we want to introduce is the Islay Canoe Club (ICC) and Kayak Wild Islay (KWI).

Kayal Wild Islay is a local business targeted at tourism whilst providing the use of their equipment to the local Islay Canoe Club which provides this leisure pursuit the locals at very low cost.

As an activity, sea kayaking is a hugely beneficial as develops both environmental awareness along with a number of positive mental and physical skills.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund shall be working with both ICC and KWI to provide specialist canoes for locals and tourists who may have physical disabilities and to raise awareness of this service in the media, targeted at locals and tourists alike.

Read more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/icc-and-kwi.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

Islay Ales is the third of our Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiaries.

Islay Ales is a small craft brewery producing a range of cask & bottle conditioned beers on the island. The business has been in continuous production since 2004 and whilst the majority of sales are on Islay, export has begun to France, Switzerland, Germany and Japan. It is the aim to continue this steady expansion of the business and increase the work force.

To achieve the increase in production, Islay Ales must have SALSA (Safe And Local Supplier Approval) accreditation, which is becoming a requirement of supermarkets and distributors. The Laphroaig Legacy Fund shall work alongside Islay Ales to fund the SALSA accreditation but also provide a training and development consultant. The combination of the accreditation matched with the training scheme shall not only see this small, family run business expand but will also generate employment opportunities for locals.

Find out more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/islay-ales.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

Our second Laphroaig Legacy Fun beneficiary is the Argyll College.

The University of Highlands & Islands was established to make higher education accessible to those living in rural areas in Scotland. Argyll College hosts the Islay branch, providing a variety of courses and training programs that are fully accredited and recognised by employers.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund will help to provide additional IT equipment, improved video conferencing for remote lectures and fund vocational courses to allow more Illeach’s the opportunity to take advantage of skilled work on the island.

Find out more at http://bit.ly/argyllcollege Photos from Laphroaig's post

Let us introduce you to the first one of our Legacy Fund Beneficiaries: 
Celebrating their skills in needlework, The Islay Quilters.

Formed in 1992, a small group of quilters whose aim is to leave a legacy in more ways than one, as not only are they teaching their craft to the new generation of Illeach’s but they also provide a tourist attraction in the form of their shop.

Working with The Laphroaig Legacy Fund, additional machines shall be purchased, a sustainable heating system shall be installed reducing monthly bills and a project team shall help generate PR and a social media presence for Islay Quilters with the objective of driving footfall to their shop, increasing income.

Find out more about them at: http://bit.ly/islayquilters Photos from Laphroaig's post

In Laphroaig’s 200th year, we celebrate the past by looking to the future supporting the sustainability of local businesses, community projects and individual’s skills on Islay.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund will not only offer financial help but also advice and mentoring for those who are committed to increasing employment, attracting tourism and providing a service to make island life even more attractive. We invited several beneficiaries to join us for lunch at the distillery and celebrate their work.

From next week onwards, every Tuesday we'll give you an insight into some of the great work being achieved by the beneficiaries here on FB. Perhaps you'll remember some of them from Laphroaig Live! Photos from Laphroaig's post

Happy Shrove Tuesday! Why not give our Laphroaig & Orange Pancake Sauce a try? Or post us your own suggestions in the Comments below…

Simply melt butter and sugar in a pan and simmer for 5 minutes. Then add orange and lemon juice and zest until the mixture gently bubbles, add Laphroaig and simmer for 3 more minutes. Pour over your pancakes and heat in the oven for 10 minutes. Timeline Photos
